x_snc_hack4good_0_hack4good_proposal.problem_statement: Nigeria and other countries have millions of informal traders (market women, roadside vendors, etc.) who often need small business loans, renewal of market stall permits, and license paperwork. The systems are typically manual, require presence in government offices, are opaque, and are prone to delays or corruption. Traders may lose days of income due to bureaucratic inefficiencies. Documentation may be lost.

x_snc_hack4good_0_hack4good_proposal.solution_proposal:
How do you envision the ideal solution to this  problem?

 

Which ServiceNow products or capabilities would be used?

MarketBridge would streamline these processes:

  • Source-to-Pay Operations / Financial Operations: for managing microfinance / loan disbursement and repayment; permit fees; tracking payments.
  • App Engine Studio: vendor profiles, permit application workflows, loan application forms, repayment schedule, and permit renewal alerts.
  • Automation Engine (Document Intelligence): OCR to extract data from scanned documents; identity verification; detection of missing fields; auto-fill where possible.
  • IntegrationHub: tie in with local banks or microfinance institutions and payment gateways, optionally with identity verification services (national ID).
  • Service Portal & Knowledge Management: easy-to-use portal (mobile-responsive) for traders to apply, see status, and get instructions; knowledge articles on eligibility and rights.
  • Performance Analytics: monitoring permit turnaround times, loan repayment rates, and vendor satisfaction metrics.

 

Are there any technical dependencies for the proposed solution?

  • Document OCR API
  • Payment gateway API (for fee payment, loan disbursement)
  • Identity verification service (perhaps the National Identity Management Commission, NIMC, or any other for other countries)
  • Local bank/microfinance institution integrations
  • Mobile money / fintech APIs

 

What challenges would you foresee in implementing this idea?

  • Trust and security: traders may distrust digital systems or fear fees; ensuring transparency,
  • Access to documentation: many informal traders may lack formal documents or IDs; they need fallback options.
  • Financial risk: loan defaults; need risk assessment; monitoring.
  • Regulation/policy hurdles: government buy-in; alignment with municipal authorities.
